case_name: Widow and minor son of Mangilal v. Shrimati Lilabai w/o Vrijpalji

facts.text: Civil Suit No. 9-A of 1946 was filed by Shrimati Lilabai w/o Vrijpalji in the Court of Additional District Judge, Wardha.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Decree dated the 12th August, 1947, of the Court of the Additional District Judge, Wardha, in Civil Suit No. 9-A of 1946. C. Setalvad, Attorney-General for India, J. B. Dadachanji, S. N. Andley and Rameshwar Nath, for the appellants.

facts.text: Judgment and Decree dated 12th August 1947 passed by Additional District Judge, Wardha in Civil Suit No. 9-A of 1946.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 239 of 1955. Appeal from the Judgment and Decree dated the 30th November, 1953, of the former Nagpur High Court in First Appeal No. 118 of 1947, arising out

facts.text: Appeal filed by widow and minor son of Mangilal (defendant 1).

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-This is an appeal by the widow, and the minor son of Mangilal, defendant 1, and it has been filed with a certificate by the High Court of Judicature at Nagpur.

facts.text: Suit filed by respondent Shrimati Lilabai w/o Vrijpalji for specific performance of contract to lease or damages and declaration against defendant 2.

anchor.surface_text: It arises out of a suit filed by the respondent Shrimati Lilabai w o Vrijpalji, for the specific performance of a companytract to lease or in the alternative for damages and for a declaration against defendant 2, the daughter of defendant 1 that she has numberright, title or interest in the property in suit.

facts.text: Defendant 1 (Mangilal) executed instrument Ex. P-1 in favour of respondent contracting to lease four khudkasht lands admeasuring 95.19 acres in Mouza Mohammadpur in consideration of debt of Rs. 8,700.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents case was that defendant I had executed an instrument  Ex. P-1  in favour of the respondent by which he had companytracted to lease to her in perpetuity in occupany right his four khudkasht lands admeasuring 95.19 acres situated in Mouza Mohammadpur in companysideration of the debt of Rs. 8,700.

facts.text: Ex. P-1 provided that if defendant 1 did not repay the debt on June 1, 1944, the contract of lease would be operative from that date.

anchor.surface_text: According to the respondent the instrument had provided that, if defendant 1 did number repay to her the said debt on June 1, 1944, the said companytract of lease would be operative on and from that date.

facts.text: Defendant 1 did not repay the loan by June 1, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: Defendant 1 did number repay the loan by the stipulated date and so he became liable to perform and give effect to the said companytract of lease on June 1, 1944.

facts.text: Respondent repeatedly called upon defendant 1 to perform the contract but he paid no heed.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent repeatedly called upon defendant 1 to perform the said companytract, but defendant I paid numberheed to her demands and so she had to file the present suit for specific performance.

facts.text: Respondent ready and willing to perform the agreement and accept lease deed in lieu of Rs. 8,700.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had been and was still ready and willing to specifically perform the agreement and to accept a deed of lease for the lands in question in lieu of the said debt of Rs. 8,700.

facts.text: Defendant 1 denied receipt of consideration and pleaded Ex. P-1 was bogus, sham, collusive to shield property from creditors, not intended to be acted upon.

anchor.surface_text: Several pleas were raised by defendant I against the respondents claim. He denied the receipt of the companysideration alleged by her and he pleaded that the document  Ex. P-1  was a bogus, sham and companylusive document which had been brought into existence for the purpose of shielding his property from. his creditors and it was number intended to be acted upon.

facts.text: Defendant 1 pleaded that if Ex. P-1 genuine, it was an agreement to lease under s. 27 of Indian Registration Act and unregistered hence inadmissible.

anchor.surface_text: It was also urged by him that the said document, if held to be genuine, was an agreement to lease under s. 2 7  of the Indian Registration Act, and since it was number registered it was inadmissible in evidence.

facts.text: Trial court found against defendant 1 on all issues and decreed specific performance: execute lease deed in occupancy right, put in possession, Rs. 2,316 compensation, declaration against defendant 2.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial judge framed appropriate issues on these pleadings and found against defendant I on all of them. Accordingly a decree was passed ordering defendant 1 to execute a lease-deed in respect of the fields mentioned in the plaint on a proper stamp paper in occupancy right in favour of the respondent and to put her in possession of them. A decree for the payment of Rs. 2,316 by way of companypensation was also passed against him.

facts.text: Defendant 2 filed written statement contesting declaration but did not appear, trial ex parte against her.

anchor.surface_text: Defendant 2 filed a written statement companytesting the respondents claim for a declaration against her but she did number appear at the trial which proceeded exparte against her. In the result defend- ant 1 was the only companytesting defendant in the proceedings.

facts.text: Pending appeal in High Court, defendant 1 died and his widow and minor son came on record as legal representatives.

anchor.surface_text: This decree was challenged by defendant 1 by his appeal before the High Court of Judicature at Nagpur. Pending the appeal defendant I died and his widow and his minor son came on the record as his legal representatives and prosecuted the said appeal.

facts.text: Nagpur High Court held Ex. P-1 supported by consideration, not agreement to lease under s. 27 Registration Act, no registration required, admissible, confirmed trial court decree.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the document was supported by companysideration, that it was number an agreement to lease under s. 2 7  of the Indian Registration Act and therefore it did number require registration and was admissible in evidence. In the result the decree passed by the trial companyrt was companyfirmed and defendant 1s appeal was dismissed.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate for appeal to Supreme Court as construction of document of title is substantial question of law.

anchor.surface_text: The present appellants then applied to the High Court for leave to appeal to this Court and the High Court granted leave because it held that the basic question involved in the decision of the appeal was the legal effect of Ex. P-1 and that the companystruction of a document of title is generally regarded as a substantial question of law.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Ex. P-1 is not an agreement to lease under s. 27 of Registration Act and does not require registration under s. 17.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, the High Court was right in holding that the document was number an agreement to lease under s. 2 7  of the Act and so did number require registration.

facts.text: Defendant 2 is daughter of defendant 1.

holdings.text: The document Ex. P-1 is not an agreement to lease under s. 27 of the Indian Registration Act

anchor.surface_text: The question for our decision is Does this document amount to an agreement to lease under s. 27 of the Act? In construing this document it is necessary to remember that it has been executed by laymen without legal assistance,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Document contains no unqualified words of present demise; conditional on non-repayment of debt by 1-6-1944; no reference to immediate possession or rent; executed as receipt by laymen; whole reading shows future operation on contingency

holdings.text: The document Ex. P-1 does not require registration under s. 17 of the Indian Registration Act

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, the High Court was right in holding that the document was not an agreement to lease under s. 27 of the Act and so did not require registration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not being an agreement to lease under s.27, it falls outside compulsory registration provisions of s.17(1)(d)

holdings.text: An agreement to lease under s.27 of the Registration Act must effect an actual demise and operate as a lease creating a present and immediate interest in the land

anchor.surface_text: Section 27 provides that a lease includes a counterpart, kabuliyat, an undertaking to cultivate and occupy and an agreement to lease. In Hemanta Kumari Debi v. Midnapur Zamindari Co. Ltd. the Privy Council has held that an agreement to lease,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Privy Council in Hemanta Kumari approved; consistent construction by High Courts; aligns with s.17(1) scheme where other clauses create present interests; TPA ss.4,105,107 supplemental requiring present transfer for leases; s.27 inclusions like kabuliyat create present demise

holdings.text: The view of the Privy Council in Hemanta Kumari Debi v. Midnapur Zamindari Co. Ltd. that an agreement to lease must effect actual present demise is correct

anchor.surface_text: We do not think there is any substance in this contention because, if we may say so with respect, the view taken by the Privy Council in the said case is perfectly right. Section 17(1) of the Act deals with documents of which registration

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects Attorney-General's challenge; perfectly right view; supported by statutory scheme of Registration Act s.17(1) clauses creating present demise and TPA provisions

holdings.text: All other issues between the parties are concluded by concurrent findings of the courts below

anchor.surface_text: It is with this certificate that the present appeal has come before this Court, and it raises two questions for our decision: Is the document Ex. P-1 an agreement to lease under s. 27? If not, does it require registration under s. 17

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent findings on genuineness, consideration etc. by trial court and High Court; not raised or challenged before Supreme Court

holdings.text: The expression 'an agreement to lease' under s.27 covers only such agreements as create a present demise

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, hold that the expression an agreement to lease covers only such agreements as create a present demise. Let us now proceed to deal with the question as to whether the document Ex. P-1 constitutes an agreement to lease

holdings.reasoning_summary: Derived from s.27 definition, Privy Council, High Courts, s.17 scheme, TPA ss.105,107; all included instruments (counterpart, kabuliyat) create present interest

precedents.citation: Hemanta Kumari Debi v. Midnapur Zamindari Co. Ltd.  1

anchor.surface_text: Hemanta Kumari Debi v. Midnapur Zamindari Co. Ltd.  1  the Privy Council has held that an agreement to lease, which a lease is by the sta- tute declared to include, must be a document which effects an actual demise and operates as a lease .

precedents.case_name: Hemanta Kumari Debi v. Midnapur Zamindari Co. Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: an agreement to lease under s. 27 must be a document which effects an actual demise and operates as a lease
precedents.cited_holding: an agreement between two parties which entitles one of them merely to claim the execution of a lease from the other without creating a present and immediate demise in his favour is not included under s. 27

precedents.citation: Panchanan Bose v. Chandra Charan Misra  1

anchor.surface_text: Panchanan Bose v. Chandra Charan Misra  1  in regard to the construction of s. 17 of the Act.

precedents.case_name: Panchanan Bose v. Chandra Charan Misra
precedents.cited_proposition: construction of s. 17 of the Registration Act; a document creating no immediate interest is not a lease but an agreement to create a lease on a future day falling under s. 17(2)(v)
precedents.cited_holding: no immediate interest was created, there was no present demise, and the document was merely an agreement to create a lease on a future day

anchor.surface_text: Narayanan Chetty v. Muthiah Servai  3  a Full Bench of the Madras High Court had held that an agreement to execute a sub-lease and to get it registered at a future date was a lease

precedents.cited_proposition: an agreement to execute a sub-lease and to get it registered at a future date was a lease within s. 3 of the Registration Act of 1877 and compulsorily registrable under cl. d of s. 17
precedents.cited_holding: such an agreement cannot be received in evidence in a suit for specific performance

anchor.surface_text: Besides, the said decision has not been followed by the Madras High Court in Swaminatha Mudaliar v. Ramaswami Mudaliar  1  on the ground that it can no longer be regarded as good law

precedents.cited_proposition: Narayanan Chetty can no longer be regarded as good law in view of Hemanta Kumari Debi

precedents.citation: Fati Chand Sahu v. Lilambar Singh Das  1

anchor.surface_text: as a result of the decision of the Privy Council in Fati Chand Sahu v. Lilambar Singh Das  1  in which it was held that an agreement to sell immoveable property for Rs.

precedents.case_name: Fati Chand Sahu v. Lilambar Singh Das
precedents.cited_proposition: an agreement to sell immovable property for Rs. 22,500 coupled with an acknowledgment of the receipt of Rs. 7,500 and a promise to execute a sale-deed on the payment of the balance was compulsorily registrable under s. 17

anchor.surface_text: In Purmananddas Jiwandas v. Dharsey Virji  1 , the agreement between the parties had expressly provided that the lease in question was to commence from October 1, 1882,

precedents.cited_proposition: agreement expressly providing lease to commence from a future date with rent from that date operates as actual demise
precedents.cited_holding: the relevant words in the document operated as an actual demise

anchor.surface_text: Similarly in Pool v. Bentley  2 , by the instrument in question, Poole had agreed to let unto Bentley,

precedents.cited_proposition: intention to effect present demise governs even if formal lease contemplated later; stipulation for rent and possession indicate present interest
precedents.cited_holding: the tenant should have a present legal interest in the term

anchor.surface_text: In Satyadhyantirtha Swami v. Raghunath Daji  1  the contract of lease was contained in two documents which showed that the lands were being cultivated

precedents.cited_proposition: agreement authorizing continuance in occupation operates as present demise even if part operates later
precedents.cited_holding: did not operate to make the document other than a present demise

anchor.surface_text: In Balram v. Mahadeo  2  the Nagpur High Court was dealing with an instrument which purported to be a receipt

precedents.cited_proposition: receipt-like document agreeing to give fields in occupancy rights effects transfer of occupancy right in presenti
precedents.cited_holding: on a fair and reasonable construction, the document was intended to effect a transfer of the occupancy right in presenti and was as such an agreement to lease
